audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker excitedly describing "one of the more incredible nights in Yankee Stadium history," highlighting Aaron Judge's quest for his 60th home run, mentioning DraftKings as a sponsor.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a baseball game, mentioning "first pitch fastball" and the batter's thoughts. His tone is conversational, almost like a sports commentary. He describes more pitches and the developing count. The speaker is now thinking the batter is wanting that first fastball again.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker excitedly describing a home run, mentioning the ball bouncing off the railing. He continues, narrating the ball's trajectory into the bleachers and various people's attempts to catch it, finally focusing on "this guy in the away jersey" who ends up with it. He notes that "number 99" is waving for help, possibly towards the camera, but the speaker notes "our guy" has the ball in that moment. The clip then ends abruptly.

The clip begins with a male speaker urgently describing a scene. He notes, "And he's looking at his friend. He's like, we got to get out of here." The speaker relays that one character says, "I got to get out of here," then the first speaker points out something in the character's hand and states that he's going to show his friend. The speaker repeats what the character says, "I got it," before he realizes not to show people and tucks it away. The speaker explains that the character's friend helps him and "they get the hell out of Dodge" as others are still looking, "still in the pile."

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker expressing a desire to see the reaction of people who missed catching something, followed by the statement that "someone must have gotten it". He then mentions someone got tickets and a "Judge 60th homerun", noting the easy swing, gentle bat drop, and lack of celebration. The speaker's tone is conversational and descriptive.

The audio clip begins with a man describing his favorite reaction, emphasizing a father-son moment during a baseball game, praising their interaction as beautiful. The man further elaborates on the crowd's excitement, capturing videos and the dugout's reaction, noting perfect high-fives.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker describing a scene with Harrison Bader's first day with the Yankees, filled with excitement. He mentions Judge getting a curtain call despite losing and feeling conflicted about celebrating. He recalls Judge being up earlier with bases loaded but failing to deliver. The speaker's tone conveys a mix of playfulness and analysis.

The audio clip features a male speaker excitedly describing a baseball game, emphasizing player actions like "Rizzo shoots that one perfectly to the gap," and "Donaldson's gonna come up and he's gonna flare this one." The speaker describes a moment where the bases are loaded. There is no music or any background sounds.

The audio starts with sounds of claps. Speech from one male speaker follows, as he describes how other people are clapping and feeling excited, suggesting that someone is eager to play. He is wondering, seemingly to himself, if they are "getting double magic in the ninth year".

The audio begins with a male speaker describing a baseball game. He first says "First pitch to Stan is a strike," and then mimics a crowd reaction, commenting on a close call. He continues to describe the pitches and counts. There is some background noise, possibly the general ambient sound of a baseball game. He mentions the count reaching two-two.

The clip starts with a male speaker describing how "Stanton's been struggling with high velocity" and then, surprised, comments on a change-up thrown into the zone. In an excited tone, he describes Stanton's hit as an "absolute line drive tank job for the walkoff grand slam," noting the pitcher's circle change with little movement. Commenting on Stanton's appearance and subsequent celebration, he remarks on a shot of Rizzo, "helmet off." The speaker then watches the shot again, cheering. He describes the shot of Stanton running by as well.

The clip starts with a male speaker commenting on a photo of two figures. He describes their eye contact and shared pose as they pass each other, then equates it to two lovers on separate trains at the end of a movie. The speaker notes there's "a lot of love and excitement in this shot" and the clip ends.

The clip begins with a male speaker observing "just a lot of longing in the eyes" before exclaiming with excitement about seeing something at home plate and expressing anticipation. Subsequently, he describes the scene as "absolute pandemonium" with Yankees players "losing their minds" and running around. He notes the physical contact and screaming among the players and urges the listener to observe Rizzo's face, which seems to evoke amusement from the speaker who adds that Rizzo looks like a little kid, happy about scoring. The clip then closes with sounds akin to musical chimes.

The audio clip begins with an enthusiastic male voice narrating a playful baseball scene, mentioning a "little pad", "the two Oswaldos", "Cabrera", and "Nester with the gum". The speaker notes that Nester is taking a "risky" action, that Stan will "break down into the gritty", and describes everyone, including a player named "Rizzo", as being very excited and encouraging. The speaker finds the scene "cool" and describes the mechanics of Nester's "gum toss" as "perfect". The speaker emphasizes the amazing quality of the throw.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a baseball team's achievement, noting a recent walk-off win and a few of the players involved. The speaker shifts to describing the reactions, mentioning "Garrett Cole's gotta get his ass slaps in" before detailing interactions between players, including high-fives and head pats, all delivered in an excited tone. The speaker notes two individuals in the background expressing disbelief.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a high-five interaction among people. He notes that someone "totally snakes it," but one person "hangs tough." He then adds that everyone gets a high-five and everyone is excited. There is then a whooping sound, indicating excitement. The speaker says, "this guy's got tears in his eyes, I can't believe I just saw that. Oh my god."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker admitting he didn't anticipate feeling so emotional and wrapped up in something, attributing it to passion and baseball. He then quotes someone saying "line drive" with excitement, followed by another male speaker who remarks the ball went "way over the fence". A male speaker acknowledges the episode is sponsored by DraftKings. He describes an awesome night. Finally he says "I don't know" and expresses that is was "just really cool" in a soft tone.
